title: Physical Adsorption of Ar and CO
on C
Fullerene
abstract: physisorption on a very well crystallized sample of fullerene C
was studied by means of Monte Carlo computer simulations. Ar and CO
experimental isotherms were determined on high-purity C
to fit the potential parameters. Analysis of the structure of the adsorbed film indicated that both gases are adsorbed in the voids of the C
structure in a solid state with densities slightly larger than the bulk solid. Both gases exhibited a behavior similar to nitrogen. The cross-sectional area found for Ar is 0.121 nm
. The existence of three adsorption sites found previously has been confirmed.
text: The fullerene structure consists of carbon atoms arranged in polyhedral networks that represent the first known type of molecular solids consisting exclusively of carbon, the archetypes being C
. In the solid state, these pseudospherical molecules arrange in turn in different crystal structures, for example, a face-centered cubic crystal structure for C
. The discovery of this new type of carbon solids

represented a major breakthrough not only for carbon science, but also for the entire field of chemistry. Since then, many studies have been devoted to fullerenes, which have led to some practical applications of this new class of solids. Unfortunately, this is not the case for surface studies, a limited number of works having been done on their adsorption properties.
Some of the earliest reports on the adsorption properties of fullerenes showed the occurrence of porosity in these solids. Thus, Ismail and Rodgers
adsorption, agreed in finding micropores in C
; Ismail and Rodgers had already pointed out that surface area values might vary from one batch to another, depending on sample preparation and purification, as well as sample age. More recent work

indicates, however, that fullerene powders with higher degrees of purity consist of nonporous particles. As expected for any solid, the porous texture of fullerenes is very sensitive to the synthesis and purification procedures followed in their preparation.
The nature of adsorption centers in fullerenes has attracted the attention of researchers using different experimental techniques such as infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed species,
and measurement of gas adsorption isotherms.

In most of these studies the behavior of fullerenes has been compared with much better known carbon solids such as graphite, carbon black, and diamond. Note the close agreement between results from different techniques in showing at least two types of adsorption centers in C
:  one (weak) at the top of surface fullerene molecules (site C), the other (strong) at the spaces between these spherical molecules. Recent work conducted at our laboratories
has suggested that, for the strong type of center, a further distinction can be made between “flat nanospaces” located at places where four C
molecules meet (site A), and “channels” between two C
molecules (site B) in the face-centered cubic structure of C
. This view agrees with the finding of Papirer et al.
of three families of adsorption sites for

-heptane using inverse gas chromatography. However, by comparison with other carbon samples studied, these authors ascribed their maxima in adsorption energy distribution functions to graphene-like structures (weaker adsorption sites) and oxygenated surface sites (stronger adsorption sites).
In this work we have studied the physical adsorption of molecules other than nitrogen on C
to corroborate the absence of porosity in high-purity C

specimens; to verify the occurrence of three different types of adsorption sites; to get some further insight into the nature of these sites; and finally to collect information about the structure of the adsorbed film. Argon and carbon dioxide were selected to this end. Argon adsorption isotherms have been determined at 77.5 K, whereas CO

isotherms have been obtained at 273.2 K. Experimental and simulated adsorption data are compared. The adsorption energy distribution functions are discussed and the total, lateral, and gas−solid energy profiles are presented. The density profiles as a function of the distance to the surface are shown and connected to the energy distributions obtained from the simulations. The adsorption isotherm is decomposed in the local isotherms and a description of how the adsorption progresses is discussed. Finally, Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface areas obtained from the local and full isotherms are discussed.

The experimental adsorption isotherms have been obtained with an automatic sorptometer (NOVA 1200 from Quantachrome). The adsorption isotherms are fully reversible, which indicates the absence of porosity. Dynamic Enterprises Ltd., Berkshire, UK, manufactured the C
sample used in this study. The electric arc vaporization with graphite electrodes was used

sample. The raw material was purified, at the factory, by recrystallization until 99.9% purity was achieved. To remove volatiles the sample was heated under vacuum at ca. 473 K; finally, it was packed and stored in the dark at room temperature. More details on the characterization of the sample used have been published elsewhere.

The distributions of molecules with respect to their lateral interaction energy calculated for Ar are asymmetric curves with two peaks. The largest one is Gaussian with a long tail toward lower energies, and the second peak is smaller than the other and is present even at low surface coverage. From the configurations generated during the simulation it is possible to determine that molecules adsorbed in the voids have lower lateral interaction energy. This is also in agreement with the fact that this peak reaches its maximum height when saturation of the voids is achieved. Increasing the number of adsorbed molecules does not modify this peak. CO
distributions are Gaussian and do not show any unusual feature like the ones obtained for nitrogen.

Laser-induced vaporization of graphite produced a remarkably stable cluster, consisting of 60 C atoms.  A truncated icosahedron is suggested, a polygon with 60 vertexes and 32 faces, 12 of which are pentagonal and 20 hexagonal.  The C60 mol., which results when a C atom is placed at each vertex of this structure has all the valences satisfied by 2 single bonds and 1 double bond, has many resonance structures and appears to be arom.

Comparisons between fullerene and forms of well-known carbons
Ismail, Ismail M. K.; Rodgers, Stephen L.

The sublimation process and heterogeneous reactions of three batches of C60 fullerene, in argon, helium, air, or hydrogen, have been investigated at 25-1000° under non-isothermal heating of 5°/min.  The results are compared against those obtained with well characterized carbons; Saran char (a highly reactive disordered carbon) and SP-1 graphite (less reactive, well-ordered carbon).  Dependence of reaction rates on temp. and values of activation energies for the sublimation and hydrogenation processes are reported.  In argon or helium, fullerene sublimes leaving behind a nonvolatile carbon residue weighing 5-17% of the starting wt., depending on sample origin and aging.  In air, the C60 first chemisorbs oxygen to a limit corresponding, on the av., to 1.5 oxygen atoms/C60 mol.  The carbon then gasifies to CO and CO2 at a rapid rate; higher than the rate of Saran or SP-1 gasification.  In hydrogen, while the rates of SP-1 and Saran gasification up to 1000° are insignificant, the volatile part of fullerene particles completely gasifies/sublimes at 500-800°, leaving behind the non-volatile carbon residue (soot).  The surface areas and porosity of one fullerene batch have been detd. by gas adsorption techniques (Kr, N2, O2 at -196°, and CO2 at 25°).  The sample has constricted micropores whose internal surface area and apparent av. micropore width, detd. by CO2 adsorption, are 131.9 m2/g and 1.19-1.26 nm, resp.  Selected potential applications of C60 in the areas of carbon composites are outlined.

The N2 adsorption isotherm of C60 crystals at 77 K was detd.  The isotherm was of type I, which indicates the presence of micropores.  The obsd. micropore vol., total surface area, and external surface area were 0.014 mL/g1, 24 m2/g1, and 1 m2/g, resp.  The O2 mols. were reversibly adsorbed even above the b.p.  The amt. of O2 adsorbed at 100 kPa and 303 K corresponded to an O2 mol. per 2 C60 mols.  The defect-assocd. micropore model was proposed from the estd. defect concn. and the crit. percolation value.

Nitrogen and Argon Adsorption and SEM Characterization of C60 and C60/C70 Fullerenes: Comparison with Graphite
Gusev, Vladimir Yu.; Ruetsch, Sigrid; Popeko, Ludwig A.; Popeko, Ilya E.

The surface and pore structure properties of the C60 and C60/C70 fullerene powders were studied by means of SEM, helium picometry, and 77.4 K nitrogen and argon adsorption.  The pore structure of fullerene powders is macroporous and consists mainly of the voids between the fullerene aggregates.  In the major part of the adsorption monolayer, both nitrogen and argon interactions with fullerenes are weaker than with graphite, possibly because of the redn. of the gas mol.-mirror image effect in the case of fullerenes.  In Henry's law limit, however, nitrogen and argon adsorption on fullerenes is quant. similar to that on graphite because of the adsorption potential enhancement in the spaces between the surface fullerene mols.  In the multilayer regime, nitrogen adsorption on both fullerenes becomes similar to that on graphite.  Both fullerenes behave similarly with respect to the adsorption of the studied gases.

Physisorption of simple gases on C60 fullerene
Martinez-Alonso, A.; Tascon, J. M. D.; Bottani, E. J.

Exptl. adsorption isotherms of N2 and Ar at 77.4 K and CO2 at 273.2 K on C60 fullerene were obtained to characterize the surface of this material.  Grand canonical Monte Carlo computer simulations of N2 physisorption were performed that reproduce the exptl. isotherm.  Adsorption energy distribution functions calcd. from the exptl. isotherms of the studied gases are compared with the results obtained from the simulations and with exptl. data obtained with other materials such as polycryst. diamond and 2 carbon blacks (Vulcan 3-G and Vulcan 9).  From the simulations the distributions of adsorbed mols. with respect to their gas-solid energies are discussed.  Microdensity profiles were employed to calc. the local adsorption isotherms.  Three adsorption sites were identified, and the isosteric heat of adsorption at zero coverage was calcd.

Adsorption potentials and spectral shifts of CO adsorbed on C60
Fastow, M.; Kozirovski, Y.; Folman, M.

Adsorption potentials and IR spectral shifts of CO phys. adsorbed on high surface area C60 films were calcd. and compared with results obtained with other carbon allotropes (graphite and diamond).  The potentials were calcd. as a sum of dispersion and repulsion interactions of the adsorbed mol. with each atom of the adsorbent by using the Buckingham-Corner and Lennard-Jones potentials.  The calcns. were performed for different sites on the (100) and (111) surface planes of 2 C60 structures, fcc and hcp.  The lowest potentials were obtained for CO adsorbed in voids between the C60 mols.  Spectral shifts (Δν) from the CO gas frequency were calcd. by the perturbation method.  The Δν values calcd. for sites between 4 and 2 C60 mols. were in good agreement with previously reported FTIR spectra of CO adsorbed on C60 where 2 absorption bands shifted by -15 and -8 cm-1 were obtained.  The 2 bands were assigned to CO adsorbed on sites differing in energy.

Surface Heterogeneity of C60 As Studied by Infrared Spectroscopy of Adsorbed CO and Adsorption Potential Calculations
Folman, M.; Fastow, M.; Kozirovski, Y.

In a recent study of the IR spectrum of CO physisorbed on C60 films, 2 well-resolved absorption bands at 2135 and 2128 cm-1 were found, suggesting that the mol. is adsorbed on 2 different sites.  To det. the nature of these adsorption sites, calcns. of adsorption potentials and spectral shifts for the CO/C60 system were performed.  The calcns. were done for the fcc (100), fcc (111) hcp (001), and hcp (111) surface planes.  In the calcns., the 6-exponential and the Lennard-Jones potentials were used.  A no. of adsorption sites were chosen.  These included the void space between 4, 3, and 2 neighboring C60 mols. and the center of the hexagon and the pentagon on the C60 surface.  The calcd. potentials and spectral shifts clearly indicate that adsorption sites in the voids between the C60 mols. are preferred energetically over sites on top of single C60 mols.  Comparison is made between results obtained with the 2 potentials and with results obtained previously with the 2 other carbon allotropes: graphite and diamond.

Gas-solid partition coeffs. of 22 solute gases and vapors on a sample of fullerene were obtained by a chromatog. method (elution by characteristic point).  Anal. of these coeffs. by the solvation equation of Abraham shows that solute dipolarity/polarizability, and H-bond acidity, as well as general dispersion interactions can influence adsorption; the fullerene is weakly polarizable, and has some H-bond basicity, commensurate with its behavior as a giant closed-cage alkene rather than an arom. mol.

Adsorption of krypton at 77 K on fullerene C60, graphitized carbon black and diamond
Kratschmer, W.; Rathousk, J.; Zukal, A.

Adsorption of Kr at 77 K on fullerene C60, graphitized C black and nanocryst. synthetic diamond was studied.  The shape of the isotherm on nanocryst. synthetic diamond indicates that the adsorption mechanism follows predominantly monolayer-multilayer adsorption.  The isotherm on graphitized C black is characterized by a step-like form, at the lowest surface coverage the amt. adsorbed obeying Henry's equation.  The isotherm on fullerene is similar to that on graphitized C black in the low-pressure region.  At relative pressures <0.005, both isotherms have a sigmoidal shape, the only difference being that the cooperative build-up of the 1st layer ends at a lower coverage on fullerene.  The comparison of isotherms on fullerene and graphitized C black showed that Kr is adsorbed on both solids by the same mechanism at a surface coverage <0.3.
